name: Series Circuits
what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in series circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and the application of potential dividers.
why: Series circuits are used in many applications including voltage regulation, sensor circuits, and safety systems. Understanding series behaviour is essential for circuit design and troubleshooting.

items.title: I can identify a series circuit and explain that current is the same at all points
items.what: In a series circuit, components are connected in a single path with no branches. The same current flows through every component because there is only one path for electrons.
items.why: Understanding that current is constant in series helps predict circuit behaviour and explains why breaking one part stops the entire circuit.
items.example: In a series circuit with a 6 V battery and two resistors, if an ammeter reads 0.3 A before the first resistor, it will also read 0.3 A between the resistors and after the second resistor.

items.title: I can explain that potential difference is shared between components in a series circuit
items.what: The sum of potential differences across all components equals the supply voltage: V_supply = V‚ÇÅ + V‚ÇÇ + ... + V‚Çô. Each component's share depends on its resistance.
items.why: This principle explains how energy is distributed in a circuit and why components with higher resistance receive more energy per charge.
items.example: A 12 V battery powers two resistors in series. If the first resistor has 8 V across it, the second must have 12 - 8 = 4 V across it. The total is always 12 V.

items.title: I can calculate equivalent resistance in series using R_eq = R‚ÇÅ + R‚ÇÇ + ... + R‚Çô
items.what: The equivalent resistance of resistors in series is the sum of individual resistances. This single value can replace all the resistors for circuit analysis.
items.why: Calculating equivalent resistance simplifies complex circuits, making it easier to find total current and analyse circuit behaviour.
items.example: Three resistors of 10 Œ©, 20 Œ©, and 30 Œ© in series have equivalent resistance R_eq = 10 + 20 + 30 = 60 Œ©. A 12 V battery would produce I = 12/60 = 0.2 A.

items.title: I can analyse potential divider circuits and calculate output voltage
items.what: A potential divider uses two resistors in series to produce an output voltage that is a fraction of the input. The formula is V_out = V_in √ó R‚ÇÇ/(R‚ÇÅ + R‚ÇÇ).
items.why: Potential dividers are used in sensor circuits, volume controls, and anywhere a reduced or adjustable voltage is needed from a fixed supply.
items.example: A 12 V supply connects to a potential divider with R‚ÇÅ = 3 kŒ© and R‚ÇÇ = 1 kŒ©. Output voltage is V_out = 12 √ó 1000/(3000 + 1000) = 12 √ó 0.25 = 3 V.

items.title: I can use I-V graphs to predict equivalent resistance of components in series
items.what: For series components, add the potential differences at each current value to construct the combined I-V graph. The equivalent resistance is found from the new line's gradient.
items.why: Graphical methods allow analysis of non-ohmic components in series, where simple addition of resistances does not apply.
items.example: Two components in series each need 4 V for 1 A of current. In series, the combination needs 4 + 4 = 8 V for 1 A. The equivalent resistance at this point is 8/1 = 8 Œ©.
